Literature Review: Ferritins are ubiquitous iron storage proteins that play a crucial role in iron homeostasis and detoxification across the animal and plant kingdoms. These proteins are characterized by their ability to sequester iron in a non-toxic, bioavailable form, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage while ensuring a readily accessible iron reserve. Ferritin exists in two primary forms: holo ferritin, which is iron-loaded, and apo ferritin, which is iron-free. The dual functionality of ferritin, encompassing both iron supplementation and nutrient delivery, has garnered significant attention in various scientific domains, including food science, nutrition, medicine, and materials science. This literature review delves into the structural aspects of animal and plant ferritins, explores the iron supplementation capabilities of holo ferritin, and examines the potential of apo ferritin as a nanovehicle for nutrient and bioactive compound delivery. Recent advancements in these areas are highlighted, alongside a discussion on the challenges and future prospects for the multifunctional applications of ferritins. The structure of ferritin is highly conserved across species, featuring a spherical shell composed of 24 subunits that self-assemble to form a hollow nanocage. This unique architecture enables ferritin to store up to 4,500 iron atoms in its central cavity in the form of ferrihydrite, a mineralized iron core. The holo form of ferritin, rich in iron, has been extensively studied for its role in iron supplementation. Research has demonstrated that holo ferritin from both animal and plant sources can effectively enhance iron bioavailability and mitigate iron deficiency anemia, a prevalent global health issue. For instance, studies have shown that iron from holo ferritin is absorbed more efficiently than inorganic iron supplements, with reduced gastrointestinal side effects. This makes holo ferritin an attractive option for dietary iron fortification and therapeutic interventions. On the other hand, the apo form of ferritin, devoid of iron, has emerged as a promising nanocarrier for the encapsulation and targeted delivery of nutrients and bioactive compounds. The apo ferritin nanocage can be engineered to encapsulate a wide range of molecules, including vitamins, minerals, antioxidants, and drugs, owing to its reversible disassembly and reassembly properties under specific pH and ionic strength conditions. This capability has been leveraged in the development of novel delivery systems aimed at enhancing the stability, bioavailability, and controlled release of encapsulated substances. For example, apo ferritin has been utilized to encapsulate and protect sensitive bioactive compounds from degradation during food processing and storage, as well as to facilitate their targeted delivery in the gastrointestinal tract. Recent advancements in the field have further expanded the potential applications of ferritin. Innovations in protein engineering and nanotechnology have enabled the customization of ferritin nanocages for specific delivery purposes, such as the targeted delivery of anticancer drugs to tumor cells. Additionally, the exploration of plant-derived ferritins has opened new avenues for the development of sustainable and biocompatible delivery systems. Despite these promising developments, several challenges remain to be addressed. These include the need for scalable production methods, the optimization of encapsulation efficiency, and the assessment of long-term safety and efficacy in human applications. Future research directions may focus on the integration of ferritin-based systems with other nanotechnologies, the exploration of novel bioactive compounds for encapsulation, and the development of multifunctional ferritin constructs with combined therapeutic and diagnostic capabilities. In conclusion, ferritins represent a versatile class of proteins with significant potential in iron supplementation and nutrient delivery. The holo and apo forms of ferritin offer distinct yet complementary functionalities that can be harnessed to address critical challenges in nutrition and medicine. Continued research and innovation in this field hold promise for the development of advanced ferritin-based solutions with broad applications in health and wellness.
